Edgy black haired character gets transported into isekai world, his party is full of hot 10/10 waifus who will do everything for him, he has a cool black sword and is really fast. Thats almost all the similarities but kage no jitsu is actually self aware and its "MC never breaks character" gimmick is really fucking funny. I think that if you were into isekai around the 2010s, kage no jitsu will bring back this nostalgia to you, with a good production and hilarious MC.

So my first impression of this show was something of deja vu. Within the first 30 seconds of the first episode, I was certain I was re-experiencing a series I had already watched. By the one minute mark, I was thinking "This is Monogatari isn't it?" The feeling then bludgeoned me for the remainder of the show. This really isn't odd considering both shows shared much of their talent. Sadly, Arakawa Under the Bridge doesn't reach the highs of the Monogatari series. If you enjoyed this series, I wholeheartedly recommend Monogatari (either watch in release order or look up a watch order guide).

The Eminence in Shadow is far inferior to Overlord in many ways, but they both contain the incredibly specific trope of a guy being reincarnated into a fantasy world where he suddenly gains much power and many subordinates, and as a result he has to keep up the act of a perfect and all-knowing leader (when he is really no such thing).

The First anime focuses on the main character Naho getting adressed by a letter from her future self in the next 10 years while the Latter anime has the main character Kaizaki obtain a pill to turn back 10 years of just his appearance and not the timeline, turning to a 17 year old looking kid. While both anime focus on the perspective of the MCs gone wrong in the future they have got another chance to change their regretful destinies, where Naho has to look out for Kakeru, on the other hand Kaizaki has to cope out with the new high school life. Both seem to be a cup of romance, slice of life and comedic heartwarming experience , feeling similar on addressing their pasts.

entry.title: Neon Genesis Evangelion: The End of Evangelion
Shingeki no Kyojin: The Final Season - Kanketsu-hen

data.content: These are the finales of their respective shows which are considered to be cult classics amongst the Anime community. (Unironically, was also split into 2 parts). Both are a culmination of stories about humanity preventing the loss of human-kind; albeit, at the cost of another. Genocide and Apocalyptic events occur at a grand scale under the hands of protagonists whom suffer from the realities of the world. The stories end with a divisive result that will sure to haunt audiences.
The female leads in both are similar in appearance and in their fighting style. In both cases the girl's father was killed and they are out to render justice to those responsible.
both girls have some form of disease killing them and enjoy their last days with their love of their life.

entry.title: Kubikiri Cycle: Aoiro Savant to Zaregototsukai

data.content: Both shows are majorly dialogue-focused, have excellent shot composition, dense & foreshadowing conversations between characters, & an air of mystery. Both are also visually stunning and esoteric.

Both shows inflict emotional damage at regular intervals & aren't afraid of killing off their characters. Both shows have a song you'll never forget: Gurren Lagann has "Sorairo Days", Edgerunners has "I Really Want To Stay At Your House" There are more similarities, but they'd start to go into spoiler territory. It's a shame I can't mention it, as the most similar aspect between them is also the biggest spoiler.

Same vibe about demons lending their power to humans (at a cost), both have visually stunning animation, a god-tier OP, darker plot lines, & similar character dynamics: -Goofy & clueless main character, who becomes badass when he needs to be -Female side character who starts out annoying at first, then grows on you -Quiet & serious male side character carrying a lot of baggage, but opens up later on
Both animes portray the struggle of human relationships, especially those family and marriage related.

If Madoka Magica is the magical girl equivalent to Evangelion, then Wish Upon The Pleiades is the magical girl equivalent to Gurren Lagann. Wish Upon the Pleiades does everything Gurren Lagann does. Just as Gurren Lagann encapsulates the over-the-top, action-packed nature of the mecha genre, Wish Upon The Pleiades is nothing but magical girl friendship and serenity. Both series are also stylistically similar.
both mc's use their powers to gain authority

entry.title: Tensei Oujo to Tensai Reijou no Mahou Kakumei

data.content: Both series have well animated action and star two female leads with opposite personalities who grow with and because of the other. In both cases, the leads are involved in an organization/study that is considered private in their societies. Where Lycoris Recoil focuses more on the building of trust and friendship, The Magical Revolution of the Reincarnated Princess and the Genius Young Lady focuses more on the romantic undertones between the two leads. There's enough of a through line, in my eyes, for someone that enjoys one approach to appreciate the other as well!

- Both are set in mostly realistic worlds with one major fantasy element (Zodiac animals for Fruits Basket, as opposed to Fairies in Sugar Apple) - Borh have, at least in my opinion, realistic and heartwarming romance which is somewhat predictable from the beginning, but still enjoyable. - Both are much darker than they first appear on the surface (desperate Fruits Basket in its later seasons) - Comedic side character(s) (Mythril Lid Pod is a combination of Uotani, Kakeru, and Momiji, nobody can convince me otherwise.)
Both has a similar beggining of a girl meeting an older men and helping him, which changes both of their lives
Amazing animation, great fight scene, great plot

Both male MCs are transported to another world after dying. They also get some cheat skills/powers making them pretty powerful in what they are doing. The main similarity is town/farm development from scratch, populated with various race from monsters to elves.

Both animes relate to time travel as the main focus. I think if you liked Steins; Gate then Link Click is a good choice when thinking of other animes to watch! Both have the sense of thrill and mystery. My personal opinion is that Link Click is much more engaging and is more fast paced than Steins; Gate. However if your in for the long haul Steins; Gate is good too! ANYWAYS TLDR, both will have you on the edge of your seat :) 10/10 recommend.
Both are related to cultivation and are chinese animes. Have amazing graphics, and MCs get stronger and progresses amazingly.

Weak to strong MC, luck happens upon. But the novel of Quanzhi Fashi is amazing! However Xing Yu Siwan Nian has thousand times better graphics in terms of animation xD. Quanzhi Fashi has little to no appeal as an anime.
Both anime; ✿ involve some form of amnesia ✿ there is a conection to a different world/dimension ✿ are reverse harem anime
Both anime are about the wholesome day-to-day little adventures of a group of pretty and quirky boys.
both mecha with same topic and also the great art of 86 :)
Kanon is the OG Clannad. Heartwarming characters, Heartbreaking Story. You will definitley like Kanon if you liked Clannad & Afterstory. absolute peak fiction

Space opera is a genre with a small, but devoted fanbase. There are very few recognizable space opera anime. Gundam Wing may now be considered an old anime, but it was a popular entry point into the Gundam franchise and an excellent example of space opera anime. Uchuu Senkan Yamato 2199 is a more recent space opera anime, but did not gain the same level of popularity outside of Japan. However, it is easily one of the best space opera anime in the last 15 years, which speaks more to the lack of new space opera anime. You will undoubtedly enjoy these series.
The main characters have a very peculiar face and that's a main driver of the action.

...it's not entirely-alike, but the third episode is somehow struck me with the feeling 'what it would be like if flcl were made for grown-ups.' overall, the story is done in a fantastically adult, interesting, no-shit way; so is the direction. one of the best animes i've ever seen
Both are amazing love stories revolving around introverts and both are also kind of sad (in different ways), if you liked any one of the above, yhe other is worth checking out.

Protagonists are high school aged females in a Victorian era. Both series feature young characters working in secrecy to overcome the ruling class, no matter the cost (physical, social, emotional). Both thought provoking and mystery driven, with similar period settings.

data.content: Himuro reminds me so much of Takeo. Both characters has this very cute internal monologue for their loved ones. Also, if you want your heart being ripped to shreds with each episode, realizing how lonely and single you are, then I would recommend watching both series.

Parts of GaoGaiGar are definitely visually similar to Evangelion -- they both have great high-detail animation, and the screens and explosions definitely reminded me of Evangelion. GaoGaiGar is a happier, technologically cooler, more family-friendly version of Evangelion which in some ways makes it superior to Evangelion for me because it removes the scary psychological scenes and existential angst.

Both of two stories characters developed in the similar way. Both of them are naive in their world and try to learn new things -Similar atmosphere -Similar art -Beautiful work of music -Both manifests happiness beside bitterness of life
Both are very good romcoms

The things that connect Komi Can't Communicate and School Rumble the greatest are their eccentric and fun casts of characters. Every character gets their fair share of screen time as well. The plots are simple enough too, there are just high schoolers doing regular high schooler things. There is romance in both, but the romance in School Rumble is more prevalent as it has relationships set up between the side characters, unlike Komi-san which mainly focuses on the relationship between the main characters. If you want a casual watch filled with lots of light-hearted amusement, watch both of these shows.
Both animes have otakus working at jobs and have a nice slice of life slow feel to them.

I think the comedy in both shows gives off the same vibe, despite being in completely different settings. The main characters are similar. If you liked the humor in Saiki, I'm sure you will like the humor in uramichi oniisan as well.

Both are very psychological, dark sci-fi, and vague, with complex narratives. You have to think for yourself, as everything is not outright explained. Both explore similar ideas, such as collective consciousness and self-worth, but do it originally. They aren't too similar though, so I recommend watching both :)
The Promised Neverland is similar to Attack On Titan in the sense that neither you nor the characters know what's going on, i.e, you discover the plot of the anime together.

data.content: Both are romance comedy and have similar secondary characters Chika - Carol: Extrovert, dumb, big booba, meme material Ishigami - Misuzu: Introvert, negative, more popular than the main character

Though the plots and tone aren't super similar (aside from some telekinetic power stuff), the animation is. Both have intense changes in angles and lightings, (and without the uncanny-valley effect of unfortune cgi usage - not to open that can of worms).

Both stories feature a shy main girl whose feelings sometimes manifest into cat ears, with a crush on a down-to-earth boy, plus a quirkier friend group around them as they all have fun (and cute bonding moments) in and out of school.
Two different kinds of chaos, two different times in history. Same country. These two are two good perspectives on human psychology

Two stories of how children eek to survive in an environment where adults have little influence and little positive to bring to the children's lives. Although Totoro has been viewed as more upbeat and Fireflies as darker, and this may be true to an extent, both tales are in reality stories of lost children and their deepest fears - they just deal with them in different ways. Whereas in Toroto Mai and Satsuki have the magical Totoro to guide them and offer distractions from everyday existence, Setsuko and Seita in Grave of the Fireflies are much closer to the cold reality of life. Both are also based to some extent on real experiences, helping to give these two Anime an extra dimension, and strongly significant imagery that will remain with you long after you have finished watching them.

The main similarity is the the characters, and both plots are lighthearted and humorous. The main characters are keeping their identities as otaku/mangaka a secret from coworkers and schoolmates, and this results in a lot of funny situations of misunderstandings.
Both are filled with comedy and action. In both animes, there are supernatural abilities in which each characters are unique. Amazing action scenes with memorable moments.

Both in the "cute girls doing cute things" genre. A group of girls exploring the world and friendship. Not much conflict, but that's kind of the best part. Both are really great feel good animes with lovable and memorable characters.
Both are romantic, and also sad. Also similar in episode count (24 and 25)
The MC in Eminence in the Shadow is trying his best to be a sidecharacter, he is also very very OP and the biggest no Simp, just like in Saikyou Onmyouji no Isekai Tenseiki.

entry.title: Ningen Fushin no Boukensha-tachi ga Sekai wo Sukuu you desu

data.content: Both Ningen Fushin and Grimgar explore the theme of finding strength in coming together after being uprooted from one's normal life. In Ningen Fushin, all four characters were betrayed by their former parties, while in Grimgar, the protagonists discover that the fantasy world they're in is not a mere game. Despite these challenges, both shows depict the characters gradually learning to rely on one another and work as a team to overcome their obstacles.

Both of these idol shows are similar. They are both about a large cast looking to become pop idols, and their journey of learning and industry hardships. Biggest difference is Cinderella Girls has girls, and UniteUp is about guys. They're a semi-realistic look at the idol industry (UniteUp slightly moreso), but with an overall lighthearted tone.

Both feature a hardworking MC who wants to succeed in their craft despite various hardships in their way. Though Sugar Apple Fairy Tale is more fantasy, and Runway de Waratte is based more in reality, both have somewhat relatable MC's flawed in one way or another.

Gothic feel, berserk's gothic theme is from centuries past - gilgamesh's gothic theme is futuristic, not too far in the future where it seems unrecognizable. I hate to spoil the surprise, yet both have an intense ending that makes the whole experience worth the wait.

Possibly the closest you'd find to Penguindrum in terms of aesthetics and allegories. Both are a VERY harsh criticism of society. Yuri Kuma Arashi criticizes how LGBT issues are seen in Japan and Penguindrum criticizes how extremism could affect us. Similar themes of love, sins, and hatred are touched. Ah... both are pretty much experimental too... it takes some time to get used to that type of storytelling Ikuhara does.
-Both main characters have demon powers -Magical girl -Amazing comedy -Nearly the same living conditions

Two series about high school boys learning to express themselves through music and art. Mafuyu (Given) decides to play guitar as a way to cope with a personal trauma. Yatora (Blue Period) decides to pursue art when he discovers that painting gave him so much joy and purpose in life. Mafuyu and Yatora have completely different personalities and problems, but are definitely fan favourite characters. Your enjoyment will depend on your attachment to these characters as the other characters are given far less attention. Given and Blue Period also has a strong LGBT aspect to their storyline. Mafuyu is an openly gay character with romantic relationships. Yatora has a friend who is a genderfluid person. Both series have a similar target audience that will enjoy these storylines.
Both Risa´s are longing for their first love. While Risa Hanagako is successful when it comes to finding her true life, Risa Harada isn't so lucky.
Both revolve around catching a murderer. Lots of detective work.
